abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            were substantial, accomplished by satisfactory performances
            by both the Bank and Borrower. Lessons convey the following.
            Project readiness is essential, especially in the case of
            projects with demanding reform agendas, and, it is
            reinforced that thorough project preparation, ensuring the
            scope of the project is within the capacity of the
            implementing agency to manage is critical, including a
            detailed preparation of the Project implementation plan
            (PIP). Furthermore, stable leadership in the implementing
            agency is required if reforms are to be implemented
            successfully. Similarly, a district-based, community-driven
            model for rural water supply and sanitation, and catchment
            management is powerful and effective in scaling up and
            ensuring sustainability. In so doing it is important to
            provide adequate start-up time to introduce concepts, and
            build implementation capacity at the district and community
            levels. Finally, the establishment of efficient,
            commercially-oriented urban water utilities requires proper
            incentive structures, and professional independent review
            and monitoring.

18155794.theme: Water resource management,Pollution management and environmental health
18155794.trustfund:
TF037970-MALAWI - NATIONAL WATER DEV,TF037930-MALAWI - NATIONAL WATER DEV.,
            SHIRE RIVER AND BLANTYRE WATER SUPPLY,TF032427-MALAWI - WATER AND SANITATION,TF037081-MALAWI - NATIONAL WATER
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The National Water Development Project
            will support the implementation of the Government of Malawi
            Water Resources Management Policy and Strategies by
            reforming and upgrading the management of water resources
            and the provision of water related services to: (a) ensure
            convenient access to safe water for domestic use, for a
            progressively larger proportion of the community; (b)
            provide water infrastructure capable of underpinning
            economic development; and (c) assure the protection and
            management of water resources and of aquatic and riparian
            environments. Improve sector sustainability and upgraded
            physical and financial performance are subordinate
            objectives vital to the attainment of the primary objective
            and will be achieved, within the project, through: (a)
            institutional restructuring; (b) the development and
            utilization of both the public and private sectors; (c)
            active involvement of stakeholders; (d) implementation of a
            policy framework and strategies guiding new investment in
            the sector, water resources allocation, pricing and cost
            recovery; and (e) implementation of a coherent program of
            investment in rehabilitation and in new services consistent
            with these principles, and managed by the restructured
            sector institutions.
